results.title: Empires
results.creator_credit: Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description: An epic series on the great civilizations that have changed our world covering the best and worst of humanity: explosive creativity, ultimate depravity, the use and abuse of power, and war.

results.title: Question of immunity
results.creator_credit: Bane Jovanovic and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Shows damage caused by disease and explains how the body combats toxins and disease-causing bacteria. Explains that the body’s own defence mechanism is the biggest obstacle to successful organ transplants. This is a lucid exposition of the manner in which the human body’s defences identify and reject intruders such as foreign proteins, bacteria or viruses. Animation and microphotography illustrate some of the known facts: the action of white blood cells and the response of the lymphatic system.

results.title: Quest for power
results.creator_credit: Frank Diamond, Saul Landau, Stichting Derde Cinema and Vara-TV
results.brief_description: A probing and well-conceived documentary about the values, style and goals of a new, radical right-wing movement in the United States known as the ‘New Right’. Demonstrates the power and the persuasiveness of the ‘New Right’ from a critical and a logical perspective. Key figures in this group express their distaste for homosexuality, abortion, blacks, arms control or any kind of agreement with the Soviets. Leaders of the ‘New Right’ such as President Reagan are shown.

results.title: Quest for perfection: A look at trampolining
results.creator_credit: Dick Gates and Setag Educational Films
results.brief_description: A look at the art of trampolining, with Paul Luxton champion British trampolinist demonstrating the skills that make him a champion. There are six categories of movements in trampolining, and three body shapes tucked, pike and straight. Trampolinists have modified many established dives by landing on the back or the chest, and these modifications are demonstrated. Luxton finally demonstrates a sequence of double and triple somersaults with any number of twists, showing that trampolining, like gymnastics, proceeds into art and does represent an aesthetic achievement.
results.title_for_label: Quest for perfection: A look at trampolining

results.title: Quest for oil
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Oil exploration in Australia and the development of important oil and gas discoveries, showing the productive fields and test drilling in progress. Offshore drilling on the Gippsland Shelf field by the floating rig Glomar III is shown in detail.

results.title: Quest for fire
results.creator_credit: Jean-Jacques Annaud, Michael Gruskoff and International Cinema Corporation
results.brief_description: A most unusual prehistoric adventure set 80,000 years ago when primitive nomadic tribes ruled the land and were sustained by their most prized possession - fire. Starring Everett McGill, Ron Perlman and Nameer El-Kadl, the film follows a tribes attempt to replenish fire when their life-sustaining flame during battle with marauding Neanderthals is extinguished. Three of the survivors set out on a quest for a living flame but before they can learn about the secret of making fire for themselves, they encounter danger from stampeding mammoths, giant bears, saber-toothed tigers and a tribe of cannibals. Annaud’s treatment of this film is pure realism, employing anthropologist/body language expert Desmond Morris, with special languages created by Anthony Burgess.

results.title: Queen Victoria's empire
results.creator_credit: Paul Burgess, Paul Bryers, Brook Lapping, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Empires”.
At the time of Queen Victoria’s birth in 1819 England was an agrarian society; within a few short decades this nation would be transformed into an industrial superpower, with an empire spanning the globes. This captivating four part series covers the transition with historical re-enactments, stills and interviews with historians, providing a portrait of Queen Victoria and British imperialism. Episode 1. “Engines of change”: Explores the changes brought to Britain by the industrial revolution, urban migration, overcrowding, extremes in poverty and pollution of the 1840s and Prince Albert’s role. Episode 2. “Passage to India”: In the 1850s, as steamships take British goods around the globe, tensions rise in India with a clash of Victorian values and Indian culture, resulting in the Great Mutiny and Cawnpore massacre of 1857; also covers the Crimean War and the death of Prince Albert. Episode 3. “The Moral Crusade”: By 1861 Britain is the wealthiest and most powerful nation on earth; David Livingstone’s explorations of the African interior fascinate the British public; Disraeli and Gladstone battle for control of the government; colonisation of Africa begins. Episode 4. “The scramble for Africa”: The Suez Canal is threatened by a holy war in the Sudan; Cecil Rhodes prospects diamond deposits in South Africa and asserts regional control; the Boer War leads to devastating British losses; Queen Victoria’s death marks the end of an era.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Burgess, Paul Bryers, Brook Lapping, Devillier Donegan Enterprises and Public Broadcasting Service (U.S.)
